abstract.p: Overlapping between development activities stemming from concurrent engineering may not only reduce duration of a project but also create rework risk. This article presents a process modeling and analysis technique for managing complex product development projects using optimization and simulation techniques. In order to analyze the forced overlapped process with lead–risk, we propose evolution and sensitivity design structure matrix for reflecting overlapping and their impact on the degree of activity sensitivity and evolution in the process model. Using the design structure matrix, we present the schedule and cost model associated with iteration, overlapping, and rework by incorporating many more general characteristics of complex design processes. The model can be used for better project planning and control by identifying overlapping and risk for process improvements, and for evaluating alternative planning and execution strategies. An industrial example, a tactics aerocraft preliminary development design process at a company, is provided to illustrate the utility of the model using optimization and discrete-event simulation. The optimization model maximizes the compressed time associated with overlapping and yields several managerial insights, including optimization analysis of project activity sequence, how overlapping and rework risk impact on project schedule and cost, trading off schedule and cost risk.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intense competition in many industries forces firms to develop new, higher quality products at an increasingly rapid pace. Concurrent engineering (CE) has been regarded as an important tool that focuses on reducing duration in the new product development (PD) process. Unlike manufacturing processes, an important characteristic of PD processes can be described with terms like “creative,”“innovative,” and “iterative.” This drives companies to focus more than ever before on streamlining their PD process (Smith and Eppinger, 1998). Iteration and overlapping of design activities are the fundamental characteristics of PD (Hu et al., 2003; Krishnan et al., 1997). Iteration refers to as the design process progresses, new information, ideas, and technologies become available that requires to modify the performed design activities (Yassine and Braha, 2003). Iteration usually results to rework risk (Browning and Eppinger, 2002). Overlapping activities usually affect three dimensions of project performance: duration, effort, and quality. Studies indicate that overlapping activities also increase communication and excessive information exchange (Smith and Eppinger, 1997a, 1997b), which usually result to significant schedule and cost risk (Loch and Terwiesch, 1998). Terwiesch and Loch (1999a) pointed out that the gain from overlapping must be weighed against the additional time and cost. Consequently, an analytical model of the trade-off between the compressed time caused by overlapping and the rework delay time is needed in PD.

Therefore, it is important to streamline information flow to accelerate development projects. Traditionally, the flow of information is sequential (Figure 1(a)). One approach to accelerate such a process involves removing the dependent relationship between the activities, thereby enabling the two activities to be executed in parallel. An alternative approach is to overlap the activities (Figure 1(b)), which the downstream activity receives information from its beginning (Krishnan et al., 1997). But it does not consider the lead and risk in the overlapped process.

caption.p: Sequential, overlapped, and overlapped with lead–risk processes: (a) sequential, (b) overlapped, (c) feed forward overlapped, and (d) feedback overlapped.

sec.p: For this reason, this article proposes the forced overlapped process with lead–risk model to accelerate PD process. A lead allows an acceleration of successor activity (Cho and Eppinger, 2005). In feed forward overlapped processes (see Figure 1(c)), with a lead (defined in section “Forced overlapped process with lead–risk”), the downstream activity can start before the upstream activity transfers information to it. Additionally, because activity concurrency (including lead and overlap period) usually results to rework, rework risk is considered compare to Figure 1(b). In Figure 1(c), before the downstream activity begins to receive information from upstream activities, it can do some preparation work. Similarly, in the feedback overlapped process (see Figure 1(d)), if downstream activities feedback information to upstream activities, it does not need to begin to transfer feedback information until it is finish. On the other hand, these overlapping also create rework risk.

Krishnan et al (1997) proposed the concepts of evolution and sensitivity to help decide when and how the development activities should be overlapped. Since many unplanned iterations stem from poor process architectures, an analytical model representing the complex relationships, helping seek a satisfactory design solution, is urgently needed (Browning, 2003). So, in order to improve PD processes, this article seeks to explore the following questions:

list-item.p: How to describe the complex overlapped process using numerical design structure matrix (DSM) in the situation of forced overlapped process with multiple input and output information flows?
How to build a mathematical model calculating the compressed time, rework delay time, and the added cost associated with concurrent PD?
How to optimize and resequence activities by considering compressed project duration, schedule, and cost risk based on complex information flows, including overlapping, iteration, and rework?

sec.p: To address the above issues, we contribute a richer PD overlapped process model. In the improved process model, factors such as the overlapping degree, iteration, multiple information flow, and rework risk are taken into account comprehensively. Optimization and resequencing strategy for PD are proposed.

The rest of the article proceeds as follows. Section “Literature review” reviews the literature on activity overlapping and information iteration in concurrent PD. Section ‘Model—impact of overlapping and rework risk on project schedule’ presents the sensitivity and evolution DSM for describing overlapping and measuring the degree of activity sensitivity and evolution. Section “Schedule model associated with overlapping and rework” formulates a mathematical model of compressed time and rework delay time associated with overlapping, iteration, and rework risk. Section “Cost model associated with overlapping and rework” builds the cost analytic model. In section “Illustration of the overlapping model,” using the optimization and discrete-event simulation methods, the model is demonstrated with an example from an industrial process.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: Overlapping is the process of starting a downstream activity before completing the upstream activity. It is essential to achieve time compression and optimal performance for a PD process (Prasad et al., 1998). Prasad et al. (1998) presented the concurrent workflow management process model for describing overlapping in integrated PD. Wang and Lin (2009) discussed the impacts of overlapping on project duration. Lin et al. (2009) presented an analytical model balancing the positive and negative effects of overlapping and interaction.

Although overlapping of development activities may save time, it may also increase iterations or cause rework for the downstream activities and lead to higher development cost (Roemer et al., 2000). Project managers should be careful in deciding whether two activities can be overlapped and how much they should be overlapped. Loch and Terwiesch (1998) proposed an analytical model that considers communication cost, minimizes the project duration, and delays resulting from overlapping. They also conducted an empirical study that confirms the acceleration impact of overlapping on project duration (Terwiesch and Loch, 1999b). Their theory of overlapping activities is a complement to this work. But, their overlapping model did not extend to multiple activities.

The purpose of PD is to produce and accumulate the knowledge and capability necessary to design and manufacture a new product (Yassine et al., 2008). While product design quality improves with successive iteration, iteration is a key driver of schedule and cost risk in PD project (Terwiesch and Loch, 1999b). Traditional network-based project scheduling techniques, such as the critical path method (CPM), program evaluation and review technique (PERT), Monte Carlo method, and graphical evaluation and review technique (GERT), have limited capabilities in modeling iteration, rework, and overlapping in the PD process. For these reasons, some researchers have turned to modeling frameworks to develop models of design iteration. Steward (1981) developed DSM for such purposes. DSM is a visual tool to perform both the analysis and the management of complex iteration relationships. It provides a compact representation of a complex system by showing coupling information flow in a square matrix. Eppinger (1991) extended Steward’s work by explicitly modeling information coupling among tasks. Yassine and coworkers presented the DSM model to analyze the iteration, overlapping, decomposition and integration, and convergence problems (Yassine and Braha, 2003) and developed a probabilistic decision analysis approach to estimate project time (Yassine et al., 1999).

Some researchers developed approaches to estimate duration of complex development projects (Feng et al., 2009). Yan et al. (2010) proposed a time model and scheduling method based on a numerical DSM describing the exchange of information. Roemer et al. (2000) presented a model of overlapping and discussed the trade-off between reducing duration and increasing cost caused by overlapping. But they did not consider the overlapping process with lead and feedback overlapping. Browning and Eppinger (2002) used the DSM to model dependencies between activities and developed a simulation approach to estimate time and cost. Cho and Eppinger (2005) extended Browning and Eppinger’s work and considered resource constraints in their model. In recent years, time–cost trade-off problems are extensively discussed in the project scheduling literature (Chassiakos and Sakellaropoulos, 2005). However, they did not mention the method of concurrent design and did not consider the compressed time and changed cost resulting from rework and overlapping.

The model presented in this article is an expansion of the earlier literature on activity overlapping, and thereby forms the basis for other types of overlapping presented in this article using a framework. Based on the presented model, we develop the time and cost model associated with overlapping in the multiple activities.

There are three key contributions of this article: (1) In order to analyze the forced overlapped process with lead–risk, this article presents evolution and sensitivity DSM for describing the degree of activity sensitivity and evolution. (2) This article has improved previous models about overlapping and built time and cost models associated with overlapping, iteration, and rework. This article also presents a model to estimate the early start (ES) and early finish (EF) time of activities based on overlapping. (3) This article integrates optimization and discrete-event simulation techniques to predict the impacts of process structure on the compressed time and added cost. Optimization and resequencing strategy activities for complex PD are proposed. This provides a more integrated managerial insight than those that only use simulation or optimization to analyze the concurrent PD process, iteration, and rework risk.

sec.title: Model—impact of overlapping and rework risk on project schedule
Forced overlapped process with lead–risk
sec.p: From our field study of industrial PD process, we find that forced overlapped process with lead can accelerate the concurrent development process. In this article, a lead is defined as an activity can start before it receives information from another overlapping activity. And the lead time is defined as the time from the start of an activity to it receives preliminary information from another activity (tB1 in Figure 2(a)). The overlapped process with lead–risk is an overlapped process with a lead, which usually results to rework risk.

caption.p: Forced overlapped process with lead–risk: (a) feed forward overlapping and (b) feedback overlapping.

sec.p: The lead may be expressed alternately in percentages rather than time units as shown in Figure 2. Let us assume there are three activities, A, B, and C. For example, we may specify that 60% of the work content of activity A must be completed before it supplies information to activity B. On the other hand, the downstream activity B can do some work earlier before using preliminary information from activity A. For example, activity B can complete 10% of work (i.e. some preparing work) before absorbing information from activity A. In the feedback overlapping, the feedback information from downstream activity C to upstream activity B is not necessary at the completion of activity C. For example, after 80% of the work content of activity C is completed, it may supply feedback information to activity B. Meanwhile, upstream activity B may complete 80% of the work when it receives preliminary feedback information. The feedback overlapping between the exchange of preliminary information and finalized information not only can accelerate the feedback process but also can usually result to rework risk of activity B.

Hu et al. (2003) pointed out that information constraint is one of the major constraints that directly impact how an activity will be executed, which in turn determines the degree of concurrency. In fact, increasing overlapping often hinges on two questions: (1) when does the downstream activity require certain information from its upstream activities? and (2) when will the required information on an activity be available for the next dependent task? (Hu et al., 2003). Maheswari and Varghese (2005) proposed time factor to describe overlapping, which is the ratio between the time taken to exchange any information (either sending/receiving) from the start of any activity to the corresponding (predecessor/successor) activity duration. Furthermore, this article presents the concept of information output time index (IOI) and information receiving time index (IRI) to describe forced overlapped process with lead–risk. IOI is defined as the percentage of the activity that has preformed work content before it outputs information. IRI is defined as the percentage of the activity that has preformed work before it receives information.

As shown in Figure 2, the activity durations of A, B, and C are dA, dB, and dC, respectively. For the feed forward overlapping, if “tA1” units of time are required to release the information from activity A, then its IOI = tA1/dA. If “tB1” units of time are required to do some work before it absorbs information from activity A, then its IRI = tB1/dB. Similarly, for the feedback overlapping, if “tC” units of time are performed when activity C releases feedback information to upstream activity, and “tB2” units of time are performed when activity B receives information from activity C, then IOI of activity C feedback the modified information to activity B is tC/dC and IRI of activity B receiving the changed information is tB2/dB.

sec.title: Sensitivity and evolution DSMs for the forced overlapping with lead–risk
sec.p: Figure 3 shows a DSM representing information dependency of tactics aerocraft preliminary development (TAPD) design process. A DSM(i,j) is a square matrix in which a cell on the diagonal represents development activity. A mark in an off-diagonal cell (i,j) indicates an information dependency. Subdiagonal marks indicate that the information from upstream activities feed forward to downstream activities, while superdiagonal marks indicate feedback information or iterations from downstream activities to upstream activities for design modifications.

caption.p: DSM representation of TAPD design process.
DSM: design structure matrix; TAPD: tactics aerocraft preliminary development.

sec.p: The traditional DSM mark “•” is replaced by numeral DSM to represent more dependency information (Browning, 2001; Browning and Eppinger, 2002). Figure 4 illustrates an example of rework probability (RP) DSM and rework impact (RI) DSM. In RP(i,j), superdiagonal numbers (i < j) represent the probability of rework, while the subdiagonal numbers (i > j) denote the probability of second-order rework. RI(i,j) is the same. However, the existing DSM-based models do not take into account the overlapping with lead–risk process. Therefore, this article presents evolution DSM and sensitivity DSM.

caption.p: DSMs showing rework probabilities and rework impacts for TAPD design process.
DSM: design structure matrix; TAPD: tactics aerocraft preliminary development.

sec.p: This article extends the initial concept of upstream evolution and downstream sensitivity and presents the concept of IOI and IRI to describe them. Evolution refers to the speed at which the interval converges to a final upstream solution (Krishnan et al., 1997). The speed of evolution to generate the required knowledge depends on the degree of overlapping. In Figure 5, the IOI indicates the degree of information maturity that is the percentage of accumulated knowledge or completed works at a particular time. The larger the IOI is, the later the information is provided, and the closer the parameter of activity releasing information is to its final value. So, later releasing information or lager the IOI usually results in smaller rework risk.

caption.p: Impact of IOI and IRI on sensitivity and evolution.
IOI: information output time index; IRI: information receiving time index;
tiS: the start time of activity i; tiF: the finish time of activity i;
tjS: the start time of activity j; tjF: the finish time of activity j;
ti: the time when activity i releases informations

sec.p: In this article, the activity sensitivity refers to the magnitude of rework risk depend on when the activity receives information from another activity. In Figure 5(c) and (d), smaller the IRI means receiving information earlier, which usually results in smaller rework risk. If the information is utilized by the activity that receives information too late, future changes have to result to increasing duration and effort. So, the bigger IRI denotes the bigger sensitivity and rework.

Figure 5 can also represents feedback overlapping process, in which activity i denotes downstream activity that releases feedback information and activity j denotes upstream activity that receives feedback information from downstream. The DSM is a useful tool to describe both the feed forward and feedback processes. Figure 6 illustrates an example of evolution and sensitivity DSM. The numbers in subdiagonal of DSM denote feed forward overlapping that upstream activities transfer information to downstream, and the numbers in superdiagonal of DSM denote feedback overlapping that downstream activities release feedback information to upstream. In evolution DSM, E(i,j) represents the value of IOI between activities i (the ith row) and j (the jth column). For example, E(4,2) = 0.8 denotes that activity B begins to transfer information to activity D when activity B has completed 80% of work, and E(3,4) = 0.7 denotes that activity D begins to transfer feedback information to C when activity D has completed 70% of work. Similarly, in sensitivity DSM, S(i,j) represents the IRI between activities i and j, the range of S(i,j) is [0, 1). For example, S(4,3) = 0.2 denotes that 20% of activity D has already been performed before receiving information from activity C.

caption.p: DSMs showing evolution and sensitivity for TAPD design process.
DSM: design structure matrix; TAPD: tactics aerocraft preliminary development.

sec.title: Cost model associated with overlapping and rework
sec.p: Overlapping and rework of activities usually have different impacts on project cost: (1) with the increase in overlapping, the indirect cost is decreased and the direct cost (i.e. communication cost and human resource cost) is increased; (2) with the increasing of rework risk, the indirect cost is increased but direct cost is reduced. Lin et al. (2009) considered cost involved in overlapping process. But detailed expressions are not given. In this article, the direct and indirect cost models are built based on overlapping and rework.

sec.title: Optimization analysis
sec.p: Most objectives of DSM optimization focus on minimizing number of superdiagonal marks in DSM for reducing feedback (Gebala and Eppinger, 1991; Steward, 1981). But in fact, reducing project duration is the ultimate objective for the project manager. Some researchers focused on minimizing the expected duration of the process (Rogers, 1996) or the combination of minimizing feedback and improving concurrency (McCulley and Bloebaum, 1996). Other researchers utilized clustering method for DSM sequencing optimization (Guo and Gershenson, 2004; Ltt-Otto and Weck, 2007). Baldwin and Clark (2000) proposed to maximize net option value. Because the overlapping usually results in rework risk, any attempt at overlapping the activities should ensure that negative effects are minimal while improving the schedule performance. Thus, the objective is to assign the activities on locations in such a way that the sum of the compressed time is maximal (equation (10))

sec.p: It is clear that optimal DSM outperforms original scenarios. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of forced overlapping model. The following approaches can be adopted to decrease schedule of a PD project. First, the activities with shorter duration, larger uncertainty, and recipients of information from fewer activities (i.e. activities K and L) can be executed earlier in order to decrease the feedback and rework risk. For example, activity K absorbs information from A, B, and D, while releasing information to D and I. After resequence, an appropriate sequence with the least feedback and the rework risk between K and I are eliminated. Secondly, the activities with shorter duration that release information to the long-duration activities (i.e. activity F) should be adjusted in the early stage, so the rework of activities with longer duration is avoided. Thirdly, activities that have long duration and long iteration distance (i.e. activities G, I, and J) can be executed at later stage so as to drop of rework risk resulting from feedback.

Sensitivity analysis of activity I as an example is illustrated in Figure 14, in which higher S(i,j) or lower E(i,j) denotes higher overlapping. The results indicate that evolution DSM has a bigger impact on project time and cost than sensitivity DSM has. If the overlapping is fixed, or the S(i,j) and E(i,j) are fixed, the key factors that influence project schedule and cost are iteration distance and iteration times, especially for the long-duration activities with larger rework possibility and rework impact.

Compared to the original DSM with overlapping, the mean project duration is shortened by 17.0%. The variance of duration and total cost are also reduced significantly after optimization. sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article proposes an overlapping process model to capture the uncertain nature and complex interactions in PD processes. The evolution and sensitivity DSMs are presented for reflecting activity sensitivity and evolution in the process model. We have improved previous models about overlapping and EF time of activity based on information iteration and overlapping. A time model and cost model associated with overlapping and rework are presented. While the model enables the interesting analysis with multiple applications, we use it primarily to explore the impacts of different process architectures on schedule, cost, and their risks. A GA and a discrete-event simulation algorithm are applied to predict the impact of process structure on the compressed time and added cost associated with overlapping and rework. The model is demonstrated with an example from an industrial process, a TAPD design process. Moreover, the proposed process model considers forced overlapping, rework, and iterations, which can help project managers to plan and improve the PD process.

In future research, we will integrate optimization and simulation algorithm that uses the variance of duration and cost as an objective to optimize the sequence in order to reduce the risk of duration and cost, and thereby build a decision support system to evaluate the impact of overlapping strategy from a systematic viewpoint.
